causes: Coolant flow restriction in water passages
Clogged radiator fins reducing heat dissipation
Faulty thermostat stuck closed
Water pump impeller damage or cavitation
Insufficient coolant flow rate (<40 LPM)
Radiator core blocked by debris/insects
detailedFix:
1. IMMEDIATE: Shut down engine if temp >105°C to prevent head gasket damage.
2. INSPECTION: Check coolant level when cold - fill to +20mm above MIN mark.
3. PRESSURE TEST: System must hold 15 PSI for 10 minutes without drop.
4. WATER PUMP: Verify flow rate ≥40 LPM at rated RPM using flow meter.
5. THERMOSTAT: Remove and test in water bath - must open at 82-88°C.
6. RADIATOR: Pressure wash from engine side at 80 PSI to clear fins.
7. VERIFICATION: Run at full load for 30 minutes - temp must stabilize at 85-95°C.
safetyWarnings: NEVER remove radiator cap when hot - risk of severe burns
Wear safety glasses when pressure testing
Allow engine to cool for 1 hour before work
Dispose of old coolant per EPA regulations
preventiveMaintenance: Weekly coolant level check, monthly radiator cleaning, quarterly thermostat test, annual system flush
expertTips: In Nairobi's highland climate (1800m altitude), coolant boiling point drops to 98°C at 15 PSI. Use 60/40 glycol mix for better altitude performance. Coastal areas (Mombasa) require corrosion inhibitors due to salt air.

causes: Faulty injection timing solenoid valve
Wiring harness corrosion or short circuit
ECM software calibration error
Fuel pressure sensor malfunction
Contaminated fuel affecting solenoid operation
Low battery voltage affecting solenoid actuation
detailedFix:
1. DIAGNOSTIC: Connect Perkins EST (Electronic Service Tool) to retrieve freeze frame data.
2. SOLENOID TEST: Measure resistance at solenoid terminals - spec: 8-12 Ohms at 20°C.
3. WIRING CHECK: Inspect harness for chafing against engine block. Test continuity: <0.5 Ohm end-to-end.
4. VOLTAGE TEST: With ignition ON, verify 12V at solenoid connector. With engine running, verify 13.8-14.4V.
5. FUEL PRESSURE: At idle, common rail pressure must be 300-400 bar. At full load: 1600-1800 bar.
6. CALIBRATION: Update ECM software to latest version (2024.Q4) using EST.
7. CLEAR CODES: After repair, clear DTCs and perform stationary regeneration test.
tools: Perkins EST (Electronic Service Tool) with laptop
safetyWarnings: High pressure fuel system - 1800 bar can penetrate skin
Never open fuel system under pressure
preventiveMaintenance: Every 500 hours: fuel filter change, injector cleaning. Every 2000 hours: solenoid valve inspection, wiring harness inspection.
relatedCodes: P0087 - Fuel rail pressure too low
expertTips: Kenya's dusty conditions accelerate harness wear. Apply dielectric grease to all connectors during assembly. In Nairobi altitude (1800m), fuel pressure targets are 5% lower - adjust ECM parameters accordingly.

causes: Low oil level due to consumption or leak
Worn oil pump reducing output pressure
Pressure relief valve stuck open (bypass mode)
Worn main or rod bearings increasing clearance
Oil filter bypass valve open due to clogged filter
Wrong oil viscosity (too thin for operating temp)
Oil dilution from fuel leak into crankcase
Faulty oil pressure sensor giving false reading
detailedFix:
1. IMMEDIATE SHUTDOWN: If pressure <20 PSI at idle or <40 PSI at rated speed, STOP engine immediately to prevent catastrophic bearing failure.
2. OIL LEVEL: Check dipstick when cold - must be between MIN and MAX marks. Top up if low.
3. MECHANICAL GAUGE: Install calibrated mechanical gauge at oil gallery port. Run engine and verify:
   - Idle (600 RPM): 10-15 PSI minimum
   - Rated speed (1800 RPM): 40-60 PSI
   - Full load: 50-70 PSI
4. OIL ANALYSIS: Drain 100ml sample and send for spectrographic analysis:
   - Iron (Fe): <100 ppm (bearing wear indicator)
   - Copper (Cu): <50 ppm (bushing wear)
   - Lead (Pb): <50 ppm (bearing overlay)
   - Fuel dilution: <2%
5. OIL PUMP TEST: Remove pump, measure gear clearance with feeler gauge - spec: 0.05-0.15mm. Replace if >0.20mm.
6. BEARING INSPECTION: Use Plastigage on main bearing caps - clearance spec: 0.08-0.15mm. Replace if >0.20mm.
7. PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE: Remove and test opening pressure - spec: 60-70 PSI. Clean or replace if out of spec.
8. OIL CHANGE: Use SAE 15W-40 CI-4+ oil. Capacity: 38 liters. Install new filter - PN: 1R-0750.
9. VERIFICATION: Run at no-load for 10 min, then full load for 30 min. Monitor pressure continuously.
parts: Engine oil SAE 15W-40 CI-4+ - 40L (Cat DEO or equivalent)
tools: Mechanical oil pressure gauge (0-150 PSI, calibrated)
Oil analysis kit with sample bottles
safetyWarnings: CRITICAL: Running engine with low oil pressure will destroy bearings within minutes - repair cost >KES 2M
Hot oil can cause severe burns - wear protective equipment
Dispose of used oil at licensed collection centers only
Never mix different oil brands or viscosities
Main bearing replacement requires engine removal - allow 3-5 days
estimatedTime: Sensor replacement: 1 hour. Oil pump: 6-8 hours. Main bearings: 40-60 hours (engine out).

estimatedCost.parts: Sensor: KES 15K | Oil pump: KES 85K | Bearings: KES 450K
estimatedCost.labor: Sensor: KES 5K | Oil pump: KES 35K | Bearings: KES 350K
estimatedCost.total: Sensor: KES 20K | Oil pump: KES 120K | Bearings: KES 800K

preventiveMaintenance: Daily: Check oil level before start. Every 250 hours: Oil and filter change. Every 500 hours: Oil analysis. Every 2000 hours: Oil pump inspection. Every 10,000 hours: Bearing inspection.
expertTips: Cat C15 engines in Kenya often face accelerated bearing wear due to dusty conditions and high ambient temps (25-35°C). Use premium CI-4+ or CJ-4 oil for better wear protection. In Nairobi altitude (1800m), oil pressure runs 5-10% lower than sea level - this is normal. Coastal generators (Mombasa) require more frequent oil changes (200 hrs vs 250 hrs) due to salt contamination.
